column1: Sequels: 45734 “I trust you had a safe flight, dismal as the airline was?” [SEP] I nodded. [SEP] “How can you tell that?” “I could tell the moment you
column3: in. Not only was the dust on your shoes suggestive, but you smell faintly of jet fuel & inferior peanuts. column3: up the pathway and into Beth’s mansion of a house, pulling at my camisole nervously. [SEP] Was I ever going to get over being around her? [SEP] I held in a sigh. [SEP] Probably not. column1: Sequels: 45747 His fingers ran across the keyboard for a moment. [SEP] He stared quietly at the screen for a moment, and then smiled, nodding to himself. [SEP] I watched him move the mouse, saving the document and then clicking on internet explorer. [SEP] I watched the screen switch to yahoo, and was silent as he sent whatever-it-was to himself. [SEP] I examined his face in silence. [SEP] There were deep bags beneath his eyes, and, as he turned to me, I could see how deeply worn he was from the lines on his face. [SEP] With a jolt of shock, I realized he looked old. [SEP] “Drew?” [SEP] I whispered carefully. [SEP] He stood up and
column3: toward me. [SEP] “Thank you,” he croaked, his throat thick with exhaustion. [SEP] “Sure thing,” I said, still whispering. [SEP] Suddenly, in an unexpected movement, he hugged me. [SEP] Shocked, I stood still for a moment and then hugged him back. [SEP] What had happened last night?“Thank you,” he whispered again and I felt wetness as his eyes overflowed with tears. [SEP] I realized that I was crying too. [SEP] Cynthia had died at exactly seven this morning. [SEP] Mind Twistings

column1: Sequels: 45763 The bell rang and our snooty teacher
column3: in announcing himself. [SEP] I spent most of the long class either glancing at the clock or glancing at Anna taking notes intently. [SEP] I noted her eyes, her smile. [SEP] I’ve never seen one like it. [SEP] Finally the bell to rang. [SEP] “So, my next class is,” I looked at my schedule “Algebra with Mrs. Coudrote.” “Ah, the Cood” She said with a sly tone. [SEP] I figured it was a nickname for the teacher. [SEP] “Down this hall. Follow me.” [SEP] I followed. [SEP] Her walk was hypnotizing. [SEP] I had to catch myself from standing and staring. [SEP] I caught up to her side. [SEP] As we turned the corner, I tried to think of something to say to continue a conversation. [SEP] “You do know your way around.” [SEP] I said, regretting words the second they left my mouth. [SEP] She laughed. [SEP]

column1: I picked the ideal spot, a full block under construction. [SEP] And during the winter months the workmen were gone when school let out. [SEP] She was easy to get. [SEP] All I did was call out her name and she
column3: over to me. [SEP] One quick glance around and I struck her with a piece of iron pipe. [SEP] I dragged her over to a ditch, and covered her with a piece of scrap plywood. [SEP] After dark I carried her to the cave. [SEP] The cave was the home of hundreds of rats. [SEP] I laid her out on the ground, stripped her and cut open both of her legs: that was to draw the rats. [SEP] Three days later I went back and there was nothing left.

column1: Sequels: none Arenn stood high on the cliff, looking down at the smoldering ruins, the smoke blowing into the westward setting sun. [SEP] The Tall King was deposed, and after centuries of slavery, our people were finally freed, but at what cost? [SEP] The multitudes, of which I was one, stood behind our rebellious leader as she stood surveying the destruction she had caused with what I feared was contentment. [SEP] I wanted no more war, but I was afraid that more may follow. [SEP] As if reading my thoughts, Arenn turned and looked deep into my eyes. [SEP] “You, child,” she said, beckoning to me. [SEP] My heart pounding, I slowly
column3: towards her. [SEP] Odd, but I had never thought of our leader as beautiful before, only sly. [SEP] Now she seemed to have the beauty of a raven silently flying overhead, an ebony silhouette against the fire-red sky. [SEP] “Child,” she said again, “Why do you frown so? Are you not happy to be released after so many long years of imprisonment?” “Of course,” I said, but even as I said so my frown grew deeper. [SEP] I saw a fire in her black eyes. [SEP] The Lights go on at Night

column1: Sequels: 45784 The girl now known as Alice Black was, in her youth, known by the name of Alice Lepic, daughter of Pierre Lepic, Dawn, and of Claire Anderson, also of an important station, 9:00 in the morning. [SEP] Alice had never been happy being the daughter of two of the Days. [SEP] She regarded them- her parents, and all the days, in fact- with a semblance of disdain. [SEP] The night was the only thing that interested her. [SEP] She was secretive. [SEP] Two days before her 13th birthday, her parents, Dawn and Morning Tea, as she called her mother, took her to the Wayward Diviner, as was customary for children of the Days. [SEP] The Wayward Diviner had no doubt in his mind. [SEP] He told Alice’s parents who she was to be the heir of as soon as they
column3: through the door. [SEP] But they didn’t believe him. [SEP] They told him to spin the Bone Wheel, so they could see for themselves. [SEP] They thought he had made a mistake. [SEP] The Diviner makes no mistakes. [SEP] Thirteen times the wheel went round, only to confirm his words. [SEP] Alice was the Midnight Heir.

column1: Saturday morning, I woke up and saw that she still hadn’t come home. [SEP] I called Mitch and our other friends, hoping that she’d crashed at one of their houses, but I had no luck. [SEP] A couple of them remembered seeing her leave, but none of them had seen the thin man with her. [SEP] I didn’t know how they could miss such exotic features, even in that distorting light. [SEP] I caught a taxi back to the church. [SEP] It was still a mess, but everything bigger than a soda can had disappeared. [SEP] I
column3: across what had been the dance floor. [SEP] The church was completely different now: sunlight fell through the stained glass, catching dust that still hung in the air and sending a dry, healthy warmth into the edges of the room, through the stone and the powdery concrete that had been covered last night by flesh and flashing lights. [SEP] I realized that Rachel had disappeared without leaving a clue and I had no way to do anything but wait for her to show up – which, if she were in a situation where I should be doing something, would probably be never. column1: Walking out of the church, a little gust of cold air caught me by surprise. [SEP] A cold front must have hit while I was inside. [SEP] Glancing down the street, I realized that I didn’t have a friend to drive me home this time, and it was a long walk back to the streets where taxis ran. [SEP] I pulled my T-shirt’s sleeves down my arms as far as they’d go, but I wasn’t ready for cold. [SEP] Walking didn’t build up much heat; it just moved the air enough to chill me more. [SEP] After I’d
column3: about a block, a car rolled up behind me. [SEP] It slowed down as it neared me and I started to worry. [SEP] This wasn’t the best of neighborhoods. [SEP] I kept my eyes straight ahead and tried to walk more quickly without showing it. [SEP] I heard an automatic window roll down. [SEP] “Hey,” said a male voice, “do you need some help?”

column1: “I know your family. Get in. We have a lot of work ahead of us, and it’s best to start now.” [SEP] I
column3: around the car and got into the passenger seat. [SEP] Before I had my belt on, we were rolling forward. [SEP] “Okay,” I said. [SEP] “I’m in the car. Now, will you tell me how you know my family, and how you happened to be driving by just now? In fact, why didn’t you call me by name the first time? And how did you recognize me when – ” “That’s enough! I can only answer one question at a time. I know your family because an ancestor of mine made a bargain with an ancestor of yours. I am here now because you called for help, and no-one else would answer.” [SEP] He turned onto the next street and shifted up. [SEP] “I will help you find your Rachel. I have to warn you, though, you won’t like what I have to tell you.”

column1: bye to the hunchback as we left. [SEP] He gave me a half-hearted wave that made me wonder what exactly we were chasing, and whether I should be wearing body armor. [SEP] Back on the street, I began to see things that I had never looked for until then. [SEP] Still in my initial shock, I suddenly noticed qualities of the people that my mind hadn’t registered when we parked. [SEP] I saw people with skin stretched so tightly across their cheekbones that the corners had broken through – people whose cheekbones had horns growing from them, and people whose skin was gathered back like a ponytail. [SEP] The yellow of this sky wasn’t just smog: it had a leeching, heavy dimness. [SEP] I saw men three feet tall with dusty black skin and eyes that shed yellow light. [SEP] A corpulent, batrachian woman
column3: along with something on a leash that looked like a massive water beetle. [SEP] Leaning from the rough-hewn window of one building on our right was something with long, green hair draped across the seven gangly arms hanging from its windowsill. [SEP] Thirty-five thin fingers waved lazily like seaweed. [SEP] I noticed when my back hit the wall that I was walking backwards. [SEP] “We, and thousands like us, have been living separately as long as there has been a human society,” said my driver. [SEP] I noticed that the wrinkles on his neck expanded as he breathed and realized that they were gills. [SEP] “We interact with humans, take advantage of them, grant them boons, sometimes even become their friends, but the majority of both societies have little or no interaction. column1: g my immanent panic attack, “we’re going to stop and turn three times widdersh – er, counterclockwise, then face east. East is that way.” [SEP] He pointed at the wall to our right. [SEP] “Don’t let the sun fool you. Then I’m going to shed a little blood, but don’t worry, none of yours.” [SEP] I blinked at him, but he just kept walking until we reached the corner. Try to keep in time with me.” [SEP] We spun around three times, and then something flashed across Nepthys’ hand and he shook a spray of blood onto the dust. column3: towards it and pressed his bloody palm against it, opening the door. [SEP] Nepthys took us immediately to the right, where he led us to a cart filled with herbs. [SEP] Spiced air hanging around the cart carried tarragon, rosemary, and scents I couldn’t place. column1: Arthur rose and shook his hand. [SEP] "So dear a friend is always welcome to my counsel and my home," he said. [SEP] "I hope soon to see you in better sorts." [SEP] They parted and Allan made his way pensively from Arthur's gate. [SEP] He

[SEP] "I had a hunch you'd be at Arthur's today," said Nathan, "so I thought I'd wait here for you." [SEP] Nathan's lanky frame, dressed in a loose, tan jacket, fit into the branch like an elegant skeleton. column1: Heavens, no, said Nathan, aghast. [SEP] "This is one of the strongest works I've read in ages. It speaks to the deepest storyteller's instinct within us all, yet is entirely original. My dear friend, you have done it. Oh, they may rail against you at first; they may decry you as a heathen or a literary savage; but while those in power say such things, others will read your tales and see their true worth. Believe me when I say that you will be read a century from now." [SEP] Allan, though dubious as to that possibility, felt some temptation from the compliment; mainly, it granted him the encouragement he still needed. [SEP] Nathan promised to show the story to a printer he knew and Allan left it with him, then
column3: home under the spreading maples with a smile lingering on his face. [SEP] He felt now that perhaps Nathan was right; although the man was somewhat peculiar, he had both an unimpeachable honesty and a certain propensity for insight. [SEP] Certainly, it was undeniable that the stories had an originality to them. [SEP] His mind's strangest fruit had ripened at last, and he found the taste less bitter than expected. The New Hunter

It was Saturday morning as Jake, an avid hunter, woke up ready to go bag the first deer of the season. [SEP] He
column3: down to the kitchen to get a cup of coffee, and to his surprise he found his wife, Alice, sitting there, fully dressed in camouflage. [SEP] Jake asked her, "What are you up to?" [SEP] Alice smiled. [SEP] "I'm going hunting with you!"

column1: Jake, though he had many reservations about this, reluctantly decided to take her along. [SEP] Later they arrived at the hunting site. [SEP] Jake set his wife safely up in the tree stand and told her, "If you see a deer, take careful aim and I'll come running back as soon as I hear the shot." [SEP] Jake
column3: away with a smile on his face knowing that Alice couldn't bag an elephant, much less a deer. [SEP] Not 10 minutes passed when he was startled as he heard an array of gunshots. [SEP] Quickly, Jake ran back. [SEP] As Jake got closer to her stand, he heard Alice screaming: "Get away from my deer!"

column1: A newsboy was standing on the corner with a his papers, yelling, "Read all about it. Fifty people swindled! Fifty people swindled!" [SEP] Curious, a man

column1: There were these two guys out hiking when they came upon an old, abandoned mineshaft. column3: up to them. [SEP] He asked them if they had seen a goat anywhere in the area and they said that one had just jumped into the mineshaft in front of them! [SEP] The man replied, "Oh no. That couldn't be MY goat, my goat was tied to a railroad tie."
